I am not sure where you are getting your info on waste water plants but yes they do overflow caused by unexpected water flows. The treatment used in theses cases is tertiary treatment which is using chlorine. How ever the chlorine is removed before it is sent to the water shed.  Another form of treatment to remove the pharmaceuticals in a water system is using an AOP using  a high intensity UV system. This is a very new form of treatment in water supplies .

Rich Chlorine is actually easy to remove it is volatile and actually removes itself when exposed to atmospheric pressure. It can be accelerated by exposure to sunlight band spectrum. The combination that a lot of places use is  chloramine which is a chlorine and ammonia based product that resists flashing and is less expensive to use. Both compounds are easily removed using a carbon based filtration system but since the carbon absorbs the products and does not change it you then have a carbon contaminated with the products you removed from the water.
